Exercise: Suspension Trainer with Grips Straight Hip Leg Curl
Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Adjust the suspension trainer handles to about knee height. Lie on your back with your heels in the handles, legs extended, and arms by your sides for support.
2. Engage your core and lift your hips off the floor, forming a straight line from your shoulders to your heels.
3. Bend your knees to pull with your heels towards your glutes and stop just before they touch together.
4. Slowly extend your legs back to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Perform the movement with a steady and controlled tempo to maximize muscle engagement and prevent injury.
2. Breathe steadily: exhale as you curl your legs and inhale as you extend them back.
3. Focus on using your hamstrings and glutes to perform the leg curl, avoiding excessive use of your lower back.
Primary Activating Muscles: Hamstrings (Biceps Femoris, Semitendinosus, Semimembranosus), Glutes (gluteus maximus, gluteus mideus)
Secondary Activating Muscles: Calves (Gastrocnemius, Soleus), Abdominals (Rectus Abdominis, Obliques), Hip Flexors (Iliopsoas)

Exercise: Suspension Trainer with Grips Supine Crunch
Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Adjust the suspension trainer handles to about knee height. Sit on your hips with your heels in the handles and legs extended straight, and place your arms by your sides for support. 
2. Engage your core and lift your hips off the floor while keeping your legs straight. 
3. Curl your knees towards your chest, and stop just before your knees touch your chest.
4. Slowly bring your legs back to starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Keep your core tight to maximize muscle engagement and prevent your back from arching
2. Start with a smaller range of motion and gradually increase as your strength improves.
3. Incorporate this exercise into your routine for a comprehensive core workout.

Exercise: Suspension Trainer with Grips triceps extension
Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Adjust the suspension trainer handles to about waist height. Stand facing the handles, holding the handles with an overhand grip (palms facing down), and lean forward slightly with your upper arms perpendicular to your torso.
2. Keep your arms bent at 90 degrees. Engage your core and keep your body in a straight line from head to heels.
3. Extend your arms by pressing through your hands until your elbows are fully straight.
4. Slowly bend your elbows to return to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Breathe steadily: exhale as you extend your arms and inhale as you bend your elbows.
2. Focus on using your triceps to perform the extension, avoiding excessive use of your chest, shoulders or back.
3. Keep your upper arms  close to your head and avoid flaring them out to the sides.

Exercise: Suspension Trainer with Grips Wide Grip Inverted Row on floor
Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Adjust the suspension trainer handles to about waist height. Stand facing the handles, holding the handles with an overhand grip (palms facing down) just wider than shoulder width. Lean back with your body straight, heels on the floor, and arms extended.
2. Engage your back and pull your chest towards the handles by bending your elbows and squeezing your shoulder blades together.
3. Continue pulling until your chest is close to the handles and your elbows are almost fully bent.
4. Slowly extend your arms back to the starting position with control. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Breathe steadily: exhale as you pull your chest towards the handles and inhale as you extend your arms back.
2. Focus on using your back muscles to perform the row, avoiding excessive use of your arms.
3. Adjust the angle of your body to increase or decrease the difficulty of the exercise.
Primary Activating Muscles: Upper Back (Trapezius, Rhomboids), Middle Back (Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major)

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Lie on a decline bench with your feet secured under the foot pads and your back firmly against the bench. Hold a weight plate with both hands, pressing your palms against the flat sides of the plate at chest level with your fingers pointing up.
2. Engage your chest and press the weight plate straight out in front of you by extending your arms.
3. Squeeze your chest muscles as you press the plate outward until your arms are fully extended.
4. Slowly bring the plate back to your chest with control. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Focus on pressing through your chest, not your shoulders, to emphasize chest muscle activation.
2. Choose a weight that challenges you but allows you to maintain proper form.
3. Avoid locking your elbows completely at the top of the movement to keep tension on the chest muscles.

1. Lie on a flat bench with your feet flat on the floor and your back firmly against the bench. Hold a weight plate with both hands, pressing your palms against the flat sides of the plate at chest level with your fingers pointing up.
2. Engage your chest and press the weight plate straight out in front of you by extending your arms.
3. Squeeze your chest muscles as you press the plate outward until your arms are fully extended.

2. Choose a weight that challenges you but allows you to maintain proper form.
3. Avoid locking your elbows completely at the top of the movement to keep tension on the chest muscles.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand in the center of a trap bar with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees and hips to lower your body, and grasp the trap bar handles with a neutral grip (palms facing in).
2. Engage your core; keep your chest up and your back straight. Push through your heels to lift the trap bar off the floor, extending your hips and knees simultaneously.
3. Stand up straight, pulling your shoulders back at the top of the movement.
4. Slowly lower the bar back to the floor by bending your hips and knees, maintaining a straight back. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Ensure your chest remains up and your back stays straight to avoid injury.
2. Push through your heels to engage your glutes and hamstrings effectively.
3. Avoid locking your knees completely at the top of the movement to maintain tension in your muscles.
Primary Activating Muscles: Lower Back (Erector Spinae), Glutes (gluteus maximus, gluteus mideus), Quadriceps (Quadriceps Femoris)
Secondary Activating Muscles: Hamstrings (Biceps Femoris, Semitendinosus, Semimembranosus), Traps (Trapezius), Forearms (Brachioradialis)

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand in the center of a trap bar with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees and hips to lower your body, and grasp the handles of the trap bar with a neutral grip (palms facing in).
2. Stand up straight with the trap bar at arm's length by your sides, keeping your core engaged and back straight.
3. Lift your shoulders towards your ears, squeezing your traps at the top of the movement.
4. Slowly lower your shoulders back to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Breathe steadily: exhale as you shrug your shoulders and inhale as you lower them.
2. Keep your neck relaxed and avoid straining it during the movement.
3. Ensure your back remains straight and avoid leaning forward or backward.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand on the treadmill with your feet on the side rails and attach the safety clip to your clothing. Start the treadmill at a low speed to safely step onto the belt.
2. Once you are on the moving belt, gradually increase the speed to a comfortable jogging pace, maintaining an upright posture with your core engaged.
3. Keep your arms bent at a 90-degree angle, swinging them naturally at your sides to match your jogging rhythm.
4. Maintain a steady pace, landing mid-foot with each stride and keeping your breathing steady. Jog for the desired duration or distance.
Exercise Tips:
1. Keep your head up and gaze forward, avoiding looking down at your feet.
2. Use a smooth, natural stride to reduce the impact on your joints.
3. Ensure the treadmill speed is set at a comfortable level that allows you to maintain good form.
Primary Activating Muscles: Quadriceps (Quadriceps Femoris), Hamstrings (Biceps Femoris, Semitendinosus, Semimembranosus), Glutes (gluteus maximus, gluteus mideus)

3. Ensure the treadmill speed is set at a comfortable level that allows you to maintain good form.
Primary Activating Muscles: Quadriceps (Quadriceps Femoris), Hamstrings (Biceps Femoris, Semitendinosus, Semimembranosus), Glutes (gluteus maximus, gluteus mideus)

Exercise: Tricep cable kickback on crossover machine
Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand facing the cable machine with your feet shoulder-width apart, and set the cable at a low position. Hold the cable end in one hand and bend slightly forward at the hips, keeping your back straight and your knees slightly bent.
2. Position your upper arm parallel to the floor with your elbow bent at a 90-degree angle, keeping your elbow close to your side.
3. Extend your arm backward by straightening your elbow, keeping your upper arm stationary, and only moving your forearm.
4. Slowly return to the starting position by bending your elbow. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, then switch arms.
Exercise Tips:
1. Focus on using your triceps to perform the extension, avoiding excessive use of your shoulders or back.
2. Keep your upper arm stationary throughout the exercise to ensure proper form.
3. Use a weight that allows you to maintain control and proper form throughout the exercise.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Sit on the tricep extension machine, adjusting the seat height so that your upper arms comfortably rest on the arm pad, with your elbows bent at a 90-degree angle.
2. Grasp the handles with a neutral grip, ensuring your elbows are below the pivot point.
3. Push the handles forward by straightening your elbows and fully extending your arms while keeping your upper arms stationary.
4. Slowly return to the starting position by bending your elbows. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Breathe steadily: exhale as you extend your arms and inhale as you return to the starting position.
2. Focus on using your triceps to push the handles, avoiding excessive use of your shoulders or back.
3. Keep your upper arms stationary on the pad to ensure proper form.

Exercise: tricep rope extension on crossover machine

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Sit down on the triceps dip machine and place your feet flat on the floor. Adjust the seat height so that your upper arms are parallel to the floor when you grasp the handles.
2. Grip the handles firmly, keeping your elbows bent and close to your sides. Slightly lean your torso forward.
3. Push the handles downward by straightening your elbows and extending your arms fully while keeping your upper arms stationary.
4. Slowly return to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Keep your elbows close to your sides throughout the exercise to ensure proper form.
2. Avoid locking your elbows completely at the end of the movement to maintain tension in your triceps.
3. Use a weight that allows you to maintain control and proper form throughout the exercise.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and raise your right arm at chest height across your chest, bending your elbow.
2. Use your left hand to gently grab your right elbow, pulling it across your chest to deepen the stretch in your triceps.
3. Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds, feeling a gentle stretch in your triceps.
4. Release the stretch and repeat with your left arm. Perform the stretch for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Avoid twisting your torso; keep it stable and facing forward.
2. Breathe deeply and steadily, relaxing into the stretch.
3. Do not pull too hard; the stretch should be gentle and not cause pain.

Exercise: Triceps rope extension on crossover machine
Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Attach a rope handle to the high pulley of a crossover machine. Stand facing the machine with your feet shoulder-width apart, and grasp the ends of the rope with both hands, palms facing each other.
2. Step back slightly to create tension in the cable and position your body so your upper arms are close to your sides, and your elbows are bent at a 90-degree angle.
3. Push the rope down by straightening your elbows, separating the rope ends, and extending your arms fully while keeping your upper arms stationary.
4. Slowly return to the starting position by bending your elbows. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Focus on using your triceps to push the rope, avoiding excessive use of your shoulders or back.
2. Keep your upper arms stationary and close to your sides throughout the exercise to ensure proper form.
3. Avoid locking your elbows completely at the end of the movement to maintain tension in your triceps.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and extend your arms straight out in front of you at shoulder height, rounding your upper back and pushing your hands forward.
2. Lower both arms backward, bringing them to your sides just past behind your hips.
3. Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds, feeling a gentle squeeze in your upper back and shoulder blades. 
4. Release and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Breathe deeply and steadily, relaxing into the stretch.
2. Avoid shrugging your shoulders up towards your ears; keep them relaxed.
3. Do not overextend your arms; the stretch should be gentle and not cause pain.
Secondary Activating Muscles: Shoulders (Deltoids), Middle Back (Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major)

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an overhand grip (palms facing down), hands placed shoulder-width apart. Allow the barbell to rest against your thighs with your arms fully extended.
2. Pull the barbell upward along the front of your body by bending your elbows and lifting your upper arms.
3. Continue lifting the barbell until it reaches chest height, keeping your elbows higher than your wrists throughout the movement.
4. Slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position by extending your arms fully. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Lead with your elbows to ensure proper muscle engagement and avoid wrist strain.
2. Breathe steadily, exhaling as you lift the barbell and inhaling as you lower it back down.
3. Avoid using momentum or swinging your body to lift the barbell.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart in the middle of a resistance band, holding a handle in each hand with an overhand grip (palms facing back). Ensure the band is taut when your arms are extended downwards.
2. Lift the handles straight up towards your chin, leading with your elbows and keeping the band close to your body.
3. Raise the handles until your elbows are slightly higher than your shoulders and pointing to your sides.
4. Slowly lower the handles back to the starting position with control. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Breathe steadily: exhale as you lift the handles and inhale as you lower them.
2. Use a resistance band that allows you to maintain control and proper form throughout the exercise.
3. Avoid lifting the handles too high, which can put unnecessary strain on your shoulder joints.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand with an overhand grip (palms facing your thighs). Let the dumbbells rest against your thighs.
2. Lift the dumbbells straight up towards your chin, leading with your elbows and keeping the weights close to your body.
3. Raise the dumbbells until your elbows are level with your shoulders, ensuring your upper arms are parallel to the floor.
4. Slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position with control. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Breathe steadily: exhale as you lift the dumbbells and inhale as you lower them.
2. Focus on using your shoulders and upper back to lift the dumbbells, avoiding excessive use of your biceps.
3. Avoid lifting the dumbbells too high, which can put unnecessary strain on your shoulder joints.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding an EZ Bar with an overhand grip (palms facing down), hands placed shoulder-width apart. Allow the barbell to rest against your thighs with your arms fully extended.
2. Pull the EZ Bar upward along the front of your body by bending your elbows and lifting your upper arms.
3. Continue lifting the EZ Bar until it reaches chest height, keeping your elbows higher than your wrists throughout the movement.
4. Slowly lower the EZ Bar back to the starting position by extending your arms fully. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Lead with your elbows to ensure proper muscle engagement and avoid wrist strain.
2. Breathe steadily, exhaling as you lift the barbell and inhaling as you lower it back down.
3. Avoid using momentum or swinging your body to lift the EZ Bar.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, arms bent at 90 degrees with your upper arms parallel to the floor, and your forearms pointing down to the floor.
2. Rotate your forearms upwards until your fingers point towards the ceiling, keeping your upper arms stationary.
3. Slowly rotate them back to the starting position.
4. Repeat for the desired repetitions
Exercise Tips:
1. Focus on using your shoulder muscles to rotate your arms, avoiding excessive use of your neck or back.
2. Keep your upper arms stationary throughout the movement to ensure proper form.
3. Lift your arms as high as comfortable, to avoid unnecessary strain on your shoulder joints.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Sit at a lat pulldown machine with your feet flat on the floor and knees secured under the pads. Grasp the V-bar attached to the machine, arms fully extended above you, and hands shoulder-width apart.
2. Pull the bar down towards your upper chest and bring your elbows downwards.
3. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the bottom of the movement.
4. Slowly return the V-bar to the starting position. Repeat for the desired repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Breathe steadily: exhale as you pull the bar down and inhale as you return to the starting position.
2. Focus on using your back muscles to pull the bar, avoiding excessive use of your arms.
3. Keep your wrists straight and avoid bending them during the pull to prevent strain.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Lie flat on your back on the floor with your legs extended and your arms extended on the floor overhead.
2. Simultaneously lift your legs and torso off the floor, reaching your hands towards your feet to form a 'V' shape with your body.
3. Squeeze your abdominal muscles at the top of the movement, ensuring your hands reach towards your feet.
4. Slowly lower your legs and torso back to the starting position with control. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Breathe steadily: exhale as you lift into the 'V' position and inhale as you lower back down.
2. Avoid using momentum to lift your legs and torso; focus on using your abdominal muscles.
3. Keep your legs and arms straight throughout the movement for maximum effectiveness.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Lie flat on your back on the floor with your legs and arms extended so that your body forms a straight line.
2. Simultaneously lift your legs and torso off the floor, reaching your hands towards your feet to form a 'V' shape with your body.
3. Squeeze your abdominal muscles at the top of the movement, ensuring your hands reach towards your feet.
4. Slowly lower your legs and torso back to the starting position with control. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Breathe steadily: exhale as you lift into the 'V' position and inhale as you lower back down.
2. Avoid using momentum to lift your legs and torso; focus on using your abdominal muscles.
3. Keep your legs and arms straight throughout the movement for maximum effectiveness.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand upright with your feet hip-width apart and your arms relaxed by your sides.
2. Step forward with your right foot, rolling through the heel to the ball of your foot while swinging your left arm forward and right arm back.
3. Push off with your right foot, bringing your left foot forward to step, swinging your right arm forward and left arm back.
4. Continue this alternating pattern, maintaining a natural stride and rhythm. Repeat for the desired distance or time.
Exercise Tips:
1. Swing your arms naturally in opposition to your legs to help with balance and momentum.
2. Maintain a steady and comfortable pace that allows you to walk efficiently.
3. Wear comfortable, supportive shoes to prevent injury and enhance your walking experience.
Primary Activating Muscles: Quadriceps (Quadriceps Femoris), Hamstrings (Biceps Femoris, Semitendinosus, Semimembranosus), Glutes (gluteus maximus, gluteus mideus), Calves (Gastrocnemius, Soleus)
Secondary Activating Muscles: Core (Rectus Abdominis, Obliques), Lower Back (Erector Spinae), Hip Flexors (Iliopsoas)

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand upright with your feet hip-width apart and your arms relaxed by your sides.
2. Step forward with your right foot, rolling through the heel to the ball of your foot while swinging your left arm forward and right arm back.
3. Push off with your right foot, quickly bringing your left foot forward to step, swinging your right arm forward and left arm back. Increase your pace while maintaining control.
4. Continue this alternating pattern, maintaining a brisk and consistent stride. Repeat for the desired distance or time.
Exercise Tips:
1. Maintain a brisk pace that challenges you but allows you to walk efficiently.
2. Wear comfortable, supportive shoes to prevent injury and enhance your walking experience.
3. Keep your shoulders relaxed and avoid tensing your upper body.
Primary Activating Muscles: Quadriceps (Quadriceps Femoris), Hamstrings (Biceps Femoris, Semitendinosus, Semimembranosus), Glutes (gluteus maximus, gluteus mideus), Calves (Gastrocnemius, Soleus)
Secondary Activating Muscles: Core (Rectus Abdominis, Obliques), Lower Back (Erector Spinae), Hip Flexors (Iliopsoas), Shoulders (Deltoids)

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder-width apart and arms relaxed by your sides.
2. Bend your hips and knees to place your hands on the floor before you.
3. Walk your hands forward, keeping your legs straight, until you are in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders and your body forming a straight line from head to heels.
4. Walk your hands back towards your feet, lifting your hips and forming an inverted V shape with your body. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Avoid letting your hips sag or rise too high when in the plank position.
2. Keep your legs as straight as possible while walking your hands to and from the plank position.
3. Use a mat to provide cushioning for your hands and prevent slipping.
Primary Activating Muscles: Core (Rectus Abdominis, Obliques), Shoulders (Deltoids), Chest (Pectoralis Major)
Secondary Activating Muscles: Quadriceps (Quadriceps Femoris), Hamstrings (Biceps Femoris, Semitendinosus, Semimembranosus), Glutes (gluteus maximus, gluteus mideus), Calves (Gastrocnemius, Soleus), Back (Latissimus Dorsi, Erector Spinae)

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand with your back against a wall and your feet shoulder-width apart, about 2 feet away from the wall.
2. Slide your back down the wall until your thighs are parallel to the floor, and your knees are directly above your ankles.
3. Hold this position, keeping your back flat against the wall and your hands relaxed by your sides or on your thighs.
4. Maintain the position for the desired duration, then slowly stand back up.
Exercise Tips:
1. Ensure your knees do not extend past your toes to avoid placing unnecessary strain on your joints.
2. Breathe steadily and avoid holding your breath during the exercise.
3. Press your lower back firmly against the wall to ensure proper alignment.
Primary Activating Muscles: Quadriceps (Quadriceps Femoris), Glutes (gluteus maximus, gluteus mideus)
Secondary Activating Muscles: Hamstrings (Biceps Femoris, Semitendinosus, Semimembranosus), Calves (Gastrocnemius, Soleus), Core (Rectus Abdominis, Obliques)

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand with your back against a wall and your feet shoulder-width apart, about 2 feet away from the wall.
2. Slide your back down the wall until your thighs are parallel to the floor and your knees are at a 90-degree angle, ensuring your knees are directly above your ankles.
3. Push through your heels to stand back up, sliding your back up the wall until you return to the starting position.
4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Ensure your knees do not extend past your toes to avoid placing unnecessary strain on your joints.
2. Breathe steadily: inhale as you lower into the squat and exhale as you stand back up.
3. Press your lower back firmly against the wall to ensure proper alignment and support.
Primary Activating Muscles: Quadriceps (Quadriceps Femoris), Glutes (gluteus maximus, gluteus mideus)
Secondary Activating Muscles: Hamstrings (Biceps Femoris, Semitendinosus, Semimembranosus), Calves (Gastrocnemius, Soleus), Core (Rectus Abdominis, Obliques)

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand with your back against a wall and your feet shoulder-width apart, about 2 feet away from the wall.
2. Slide your back down the wall until your thighs are parallel to the floor and your knees are at a 90-degree angle, ensuring your knees are directly above your ankles.
3. Pause for 5-10 seconds and then push through your heels to stand back up, sliding your back up the wall until you return to the starting position.
4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Ensure your knees do not extend past your toes to avoid placing unnecessary strain on your joints.
2. Breathe steadily: inhale as you lower into the squat and exhale as you stand back up.
3. Press your lower back firmly against the wall to ensure proper alignment and support.
Primary Activating Muscles: Quadriceps (Quadriceps Femoris), Glutes (gluteus maximus, gluteus mideus)
Secondary Activating Muscles: Hamstrings (Biceps Femoris, Semitendinosus, Semimembranosus), Calves (Gastrocnemius, Soleus), Core (Rectus Abdominis, Obliques)

Exercise: weighted standing shoulder press with plate
Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight plate with both hands at chest level, elbows bent and pointing down.
2. Press the plate upward by extending your arms fully above your head, keeping your core tight and your back straight.
3. Lower the plate back down to chest level in a controlled manner.
4. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Breathe steadily: exhale as you press the plate up and inhale as you lower it down.
2. Avoid locking your elbows at the top of the press to keep tension on your shoulder muscles.
3. Maintain a slight bend in your knees for better balance and support.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Lie on your back with your legs straight together, and your arms resting by your sides. Position an ab roller between your heels.
2. Lift your legs up towards the ceiling, keeping them slightly bent, holding the ab roller securely between your heels.
3. Engage your core and push your legs upward, raising your hips high off the floor.
4. Lower your hips back down slowly keeping your legs up. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Start with a smaller range of motion if you are new to the exercise and gradually increase it as you gain strength.
2. Breathe steadily: exhale as you lift your legs and hips, and inhale as you lower them back down.
3. Avoid using momentum to lift your hips; focus on using your abdominal muscles.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Lie on your back with your legs straight together, and your arms resting by your sides. Position an ab roller between your heels.
2. Lift your legs up towards the ceiling, keeping them slightly bent, holding the ab roller securely between your heels.
3. Engage your core and push your legs upward, raising your hips high off the floor.
4. Lower your hips back down slowly keeping your legs up. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Start with a smaller range of motion if you are new to the exercise and gradually increase it as you gain strength.
2. Breathe steadily: exhale as you lift your legs and hips, and inhale as you lower them back down.
3. Avoid using momentum to lift your hips; focus on using your abdominal muscles.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Lie on your back with your legs straight together and your arms extended diagonally overhead, holding an ab roller.
2. Lift your legs up towards the ceiling, keeping them straight, and simultaneously raise the ab roller towards your toes, lifting your upper back off the floor.
3. Slowly lower your legs and the ab roller back down to the starting position, stopping just before they touch the floor.
4. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Use a mat or soft surface to support your back and prevent discomfort.
2. Ensure your lower back stays in contact with the floor when your legs are lowered.
3. Start with a smaller range of motion if you are new to the exercise and gradually increase it as you gain strength.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Lie on your back with your legs straight together and your arms extended diagonally overhead, holding an ab roller.
2. Lift your legs up towards the ceiling, keeping them straight, and simultaneously raise the ab roller towards your toes, lifting your upper back off the floor.
3. Slowly lower your legs and the ab roller back down to the starting position, stopping just before they touch the floor.
4. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.

2. Ensure your lower back stays in contact with the floor when your legs are lowered.
3. Start with a smaller range of motion if you are new to the exercise and gradually increase it as you gain strength.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Begin in a plank position with your hands placed wider than shoulder-width apart and your feet together. Your body should form a straight line from head to heels.
2. Engage your chest and lower your body towards the floor by bending your elbows, keeping them at a 90-degree angle to your body.
3. Lower your chest until it is just above the floor.
4. Push through your hands to raise your body back to the starting position, fully extending your arms. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Keep your elbows at a 90-degree angle to your body to maximize chest and triceps engagement and reduce shoulder strain.
2. Breathe steadily, exhaling as you push up and inhaling as you lower yourself.
3. Keep your head aligned with your spine to avoid straining your neck.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Lie on your back with your arms extended out to the sides for stability, lift your legs up towards the ceiling, and keep them bent at 90 degrees.
2. Lower your knees to the right side, keeping them bent together until they are just above the floor.
3. Raise your knees back to the center position, and then lower them to the left side until they are just above the floor.
4. Repeat the movement, alternating sides, for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Use a mat or soft surface to support your back and prevent discomfort.
2. Avoid using momentum to move your legs; focus on using your abdominal and oblique muscles.
3. Keep your shoulders flat on the floor to maintain stability and proper form.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Kneel on the floor in front of a bench, placing both forearms over the bench while holding a barbell with an underhand grip (palms facing up).
2. Rest your wrists just off the edge of the bench, allowing the barbell to hang downward.
3. Curl the barbell upward by flexing your wrists, lifting it as high as possible while keeping your forearms flat on the bench.
4. Slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position, fully extending your wrists. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Keep your forearms pressed firmly against the bench to isolate the wrist movement.
2. Use a controlled motion to lift and lower the barbell, avoiding any jerking movements.
3. Avoid using your shoulder or upper arm to lift the weight.
Primary Activating Muscles: Forearms (Flexor Carpi Radialis, Flexor Carpi Ulnaris)

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Kneel on the floor in front of a bench, placing both forearms over the bench while holding a dumbbell with an underhand grip (palms facing up) in each hand.
2. Rest your wrists just off the edge of the bench, allowing the dumbbells to hang downward.
3. Curl the dumbbells upward by flexing your wrists, lifting the weights as high as possible while keeping your forearms flat on the bench.
4. Slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position, fully extending your wrists. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Keep your forearms pressed firmly against the bench to isolate the wrist movement.
2. Use a controlled motion to lift and lower the dumbbells, avoiding any jerking movements.
3. Avoid using your shoulder or upper arm to lift the weight.
Primary Activating Muscles: Forearms (Flexor Carpi Radialis, Flexor Carpi Ulnaris)

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Kneel on the floor in front of a bench, placing both forearms over the bench while holding a barbell with an overhand grip (palms facing down).
2. Rest your wrists just off the edge of the bench, allowing the barbell to hang downward.
3. Extend the barbell upward by flexing your wrists, lifting it as high as possible while keeping your forearms flat on the bench.
4. Slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position, fully curling your wrists. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Keep your forearms pressed firmly against the bench to isolate the wrist movement.
2. Use a controlled motion to lift and lower the barbell, avoiding any jerking movements.
3. Avoid using your shoulder or upper arm to lift the weight.
Primary Activating Muscles: Forearm Extensors (Extensor Carpi Radialis Longus, Extensor Carpi Ulnaris)
Secondary Activating Muscles: Forearm Flexors (Flexor Carpi Radialis, Flexor Carpi Ulnaris)

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Kneel on the floor in front of a bench, placing both forearms over the bench while holding a dumbbell with an overhand grip (palms facing down) in each hand.
2. Rest your wrists just off the edge of the bench, allowing the dumbbells to hang downward.
3. Extend the dumbbells upward by flexing your wrists and lifting the weights as high as possible while keeping your forearms flat on the bench.
4. Slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position, fully curling your wrists. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:

2. Use a controlled motion to lift and lower the dumbbells, avoiding any jerking movements.

Secondary Activating Muscles: Forearm Flexors (Flexor Carpi Radialis, Flexor Carpi Ulnaris)

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand with an underhand grip (palms facing forward) and arms hanging by your sides.
2. Curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders by bending your elbows and keeping your upper arms stationary.
3. At the top of the curl, rotate your wrists so that your palms face forward (overhand grip), and then lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position with control.
4. Rotate your wrists back to the underhand grip once you reach the bottom of the movement. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Avoid using momentum; focus on using your biceps and forearms to lift and lower the dumbbells.
2. Keep your core engaged to maintain balance and stability.
3. Ensure a smooth and controlled rotation of the wrists at the top of the movement.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, in the middle of a resistance band, holding the handles with an underhand grip (palms facing forward), arms hanging by your sides.
2. Curl the handles towards your shoulders by bending your elbows and keeping your upper arms stationary.
3. At the top of the curl, rotate your wrists so that your palms face forward (overhand grip), and then lower the handles back down to the starting position with control.
4. Rotate your wrists back to the underhand grip once you reach the bottom of the movement. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Avoid using momentum; focus on using your biceps and forearms to lift and lower the handles.
2. Keep your core engaged to maintain balance and stability.
3. Ensure a smooth and controlled rotation of the wrists at the top of the movement.

Exercise Instructions (step by step):
1. Begin by lying on a decline bench with your feet secured under the footpads. Position yourself so that your hips are at the edge of the bench.
2. Place your hands behind your head or crossed on your chest with your elbows pointing out to the sides.
3. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your right knee, twisting your torso to engage your oblique muscles.
4. Lower your upper body back to the starting position with control and then lift your upper body towards your left knee. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of repetitions.
Exercise Tips:
1. Keep your core engaged throughout the exercise to maintain stability and support your lower back.
2. Avoid pulling on your neck with your hands; focus on using your abdominal and oblique muscles to lift your shoulders.
3. Perform the movement with control to maximize muscle activation and prevent injury.
Primary Activating Muscles: Abdominals (Rectus Abdominis), Obliques (External Obliques, Internal Obliques)
